comments.commentBody: Given the date of physical publication is this coming Sunday, perhaps they are withholding the complete text until then.  I'm not sure what NYT's usual practice has been in such cases but it would make sense business-wise to give readers an incentive to get the actual paper.

Oh, you should buy the book alright.  I read a lot of history, and, curious as what all the fuss is about this book and its companions, I recently took the plunge and started the first volume.  Barbara Tuchman said that great history writing should also be great writing, and this is what she was talking about.

Not important. I mean, I've read them all, but do you think I remember a thing from "Master of the Senate," which came out 10 years ago? As long as you are remotely literate in recent American history, each volume can be enjoyed on its own.
"Power Broker" is one of the most common books on the shelves of young intellectuals in New York City.  It's not my fault your grandkids aren't reading.  Perhaps consider buying them a copy.
Thank you, thank you!
Does Caro believe in the Warren Commission?

I am truly enamored by the eloquence of the our former President W J Clinton, on his spectacular narrative introspectively engaging to defining the ear of President L. B. Johnson –
This is great journalism, thanks so very much –
All authors of the LBJ’s presidency contribute to its opus for historic efforts to confront the heart, soul, and powers where the personal and collective dynamics operate in what it is (is) that make the political class engage in right solutions defining the fabric of America to grand place domestically and on the world stage accomplishing better tomorrows’ grace for every citizen’s hope in loving democracy path for a good life, as best we can…..( I proudly served in the US Army during the LBJ presidency and in the Vietnam conflict’ Tet Offense - with honor and pride to engage and part of united international proper geopolitical crafting democracy for freedom – not imposed by a Ho Chi Minh cold warring gamesmanship under Soviet tutelage etc…, yet remains to be resolved and the sooner the better )

A great review, a good mix of analysis with personal recollection.

As an aside, when the great biography of Bill Clinton is written, it will be quite interesting to see the application of his notion that power reveals character.
An excellent review, President Clinton.  You write beautifully and with great insight.  Thank you.

I have a better idea. Why not fully fund state universities so that we could lower tuition and allow more access to education. The fact that we are among the few Western nations that does not adequately invest in our public institutions and thereby condemns our children to high rates of debt repayment will impact us all down the road. How will these twenty somethings start families, buy homes etc. when they are struggling under mountains of debts at a time when employment opportunities are low? How will they have the courage to start business that will provide employment if they cannot manage to rent their own apartments and have to live at home with their parents because of punishing loads of school debt?

Higher education is important to our future as a nation. Why not invest in public state universities and make it almost "free" for students. They use to do that in California.
President obama just announced another two years in Afghanistan at a likely cost of $100 billion each. Where's his education priority?

@CMS: nations that "fully fund" public universities also practice restriction and denial -- they only let the best students even consider attending. Most kids do not qualify.

In the US, we want EVERY child to go to college, even the ones who hate school, want to party, have no profession mind, are not intellectual or curious, hate reading, etc. Because we want them to have a piece of paper that says "college grad' on it.

It is now a "key fee" to get into even menial jobs, or dead end low paying jobs.

We'd frankly be vastly better off if we acknowledged that not everyone is college materials and some kids would be happier, more productive, EMPLOYED and wealthier if they had a skilled trade or apprenticeship. And the lesser number of kids applying to college would drive down tuition costs, as colleges would have to compete to get applicants (instead of the other way around!).

Loans for college education should be in a category of investment in the future which, as was proven by the GI bills of the post WWII era, helped build a great economy and a middle class age of prosperity which has never been replicated. Reform the system at a reasonable cost and invest in the future, rather than the current system which you described.

Rather than finance low probability industries, bail outs, rescue plans and earmarks which the administration has done, from Wall Street to the automobile industry, with results which frequently left the taxpayers seething, why not finance a higher education program along the following lines.

Grant college students loans from the Federal Government with repayment terms of up to fifty years @ 1% per annum interest rates. On graduation pay the college a bonus, on condition that that bonus be used to help fund a replacement student, in every instance. People will have a life expectancy beyond the fifty year limit, and life insurance could be incorporated at a nominal cost making it feasible. Colleges, such as those which prey on veterans will be barred from inclusion in the program.

Initial funding will come from savings referred to in paragraph two; from the cessation of foreign aid to all states lacking a functioning democratic government or where there is a hint of financial chicanery, and by selling Tax Free US Government Education Bonds to the general public. Education will work again for all Americans. The kids win.

Deb,

Thanks for the Screamin' Jay Hawkins sequel I never heard before. I still much favor the original "I put a Spell on You." It comes up top center when you finish the Youtube above.

I picked up on the MISPELLED [sic] theme fairly quickly, and breezed thru this one.

The only legitimacy the Communist Chinese have as rulers of China is their lawless power over life and death of the citizens of that country.  This is not a sovereignty to be respected but one to be dealt with as we can.  If they want to join together at the hip with the jihadists they will do so at their own peril.

They are weak. If they (Chinese central government), new how to govern they would put the well being of their nation ahead political influence/power/control.

But then again, no government has the power to benefit the people when the government itself is controlled by self interested manipulators. Politics is weak and has no power to affect change that benefits all. War and finance are also equally weak tools. They produce nothing but pain.

We have to correct our social interactions. Such interaction is the foundation of every system we have. Thus, correcting the fundamentals of our interactions will result in system wide correction and mutual benefit for all. This is what 'love your neighbor as yourself' speaks of. It's a very precise science. And once understood, these principles, when applied, will free us all. But don't believe what I post. Instead, one should see for oneself. Learn the principles. And test them for yourself. Then you can determine if such principles are true. If our leaders would do this, we'd all be better off. But what can we do? http://www.perceivingreality.com

Peace to you and yours.

This is just posturing by China, trying to save face to their own people because they realize that even though they can censor search results, they can no longer absolutely control the flow of information.

And in the eyes of their own people, they fear they will look weak.
The government of China will be wise to consider that, if the outcome of this case makes Romney President, they are likely to regret it.
So it can be said you were with some SEOUL SINGERS at the time you heard of your acceptance? Heh, there's a theme seed right there.

Like DES, BPA was first developed as a synthetic estrogen, only to be replaced by DES in the 1930s for that purpose, so DES does belong in this story. The effects of DES are relevant, given their similarity developmentally, and also because of the recklessness of exposure common to both.

No one argues that "natural" = "safe" but it does not follow that one should not work to minimize their exposure to the added environmental insults of the synthetics. What does make sense is to consume natural products in moderation and variety while doing your best to avoid all exposure to synthetic endocrine disrupters from all sources. Why take needless risks? As a DES-daughter, I take this very personally, and seriously.

It is significant that the greatest exposures come from BPA-lined canned foods, a very easy item to eliminate from your diet. A few foods (such as canned organic beans by Eden) are now available in BPA-free cans, and as consumers make their wishes clear, others will follow.

The first rule should always be that less contact with synthetic chemicals is better than more. That said, people should also be aware that there that there are lots of "endocrine disruptors" that occur in natural products, soy for instance, and just because they occur naturally does not necessarily make them any more or less dangerous than something that is synthetic. Quoting the effects of DES is completely inappropriate in this article as it was deliberately developed to function as an estrogenic drug, and in fact it is still used for that purpose.

We all really, really wish Russ Feingold would get back in the race as well, but you have to remember that this is a good and decent man who was badly “swifboated” by the Koch Machine. He’s raising money for Progressives and staying involved, so we can only hope he’ll eventually decide to serve again.

The Senate race of primary interest for me is the one right here in Connecticut, where we at long last will finally be able to say good-bye to tedious Joe Liberman - the turncoat who refused to grasp that he was no longer wanted in these parts.

I also support Elizabeth Warren in Massachusetts as the rightful heir - at long last - to Ted Kennedy's seat in the Senate chamber. Scott Brown was only a minor blip on the political screen/scene and deserves to be relegated to the obscurity he so richly deserves.

Finally, I do wish that Russ Feingold would get back into the picture - a sensible, reasonable voice that is sorely missed.

The really big show in this election is the House of Representatives, inasmuch as that is where legislation is born and we certainly need as many Democrats as possible in that legislative body if any progress is to be made on our road to salvation by way of effective governance.

Let us hear it for Government of, by, and FOR the American people - at long last.

It's an immune response... of course the goal is to eject toxins...What she mentions is that some allergies may be justified, but that does not mean that all allergens are harmful. If all allergens happened to be connected to sickness, I don't think there wou

Blessing that it may be, I prefer a second line of defense against allergens besides my mucus membranes. I have found great relief this allergy season by using an air purifier in my bedroom and in my children's bedrooms. It has completely replaced OTC allergy medications in our home. Here are some great ones to choose from:
http://www.squidoo.com/best-air-purifiers-for-childrens-bedroom

Perhaps, but remember that some crop treatments were developed as a remedy for naturally occurring evils, like aflatoxins in grain crops. And many  food crops not recognized as GMOs have nevertheless been genetically transformed over the years, albeit in a more natural manner, through hybridization. If we are to move away from chemical treatments, the only option currently is to allow genetic modification of seeds and crops; that is, if we don't want large numbers of our fellow human beings to starve.

I wonder what this means for all the food intolerances we are beginning to see on the increase. I've been of the mindset that the rise is simply a function of greater awareness, but perhaps it's a reaction to the increasing number of toxins, chemicals and GMO's in our food supply

It's not a surprising idea.  The immune system is complex but it's not  perfectly discriminating when it comes to targets.  It protects us, but it often makes us uncomfortable or even very sick by attacking a great variety of stuff, from pollen to our own tissues.
IF you can even get it in print where you live!

The irony is that he probably had better chances hiding among his supporters than setting foot in the US Embassy.  The US ground is becoming very dangerous for anyone challenging oppression of any kind.

Re Ikea; take a look on Craigslist;  Ikea products in their millions are on there, same same same; everybody is disappointed with Ikea after a few years, it all looks good right away, then it's tired and it's broken and you hate it, but there are thousands of the same thing on Craigslist - and yes it is all chipboard.

People who want Ikea want to start fresh. They aren't at the stage of life when lasting quality or family memories means anything. Okay for them.

Eventually, Mom and Dad die and you really do want some old-fashioned thing they owned that reminds you they once lived and loved you and you loved them.

Somewhere in between gutting a family home and keeping everything is where sanity lies.

What is the magic mean, the exact right amount of stuff to keep? Good question.

I don't see the logic in decluttering by buying more things. Especially from Ikea and especially given that Ikea's products tend to become landfill in less than 5 years. Why not repurpose what you have? It obviously lasted a long time and was good quality.

Its like when I go to decluttering websites and see them plastered with ads to buy more things or when I look at simple living websites telling you what this years must-haves are (always different than last years).

Another great tip: we are cleaning out our house to sell and we took all of our old paint cans, extra tiles and lumber to a Habitat for Humanity Restore. Go to their website www.habitat.org/restores for a list of locations.
